review:
so far I have only beaten the first boss.

this game is okay I just feel that it could have been better.

the default controls are awkward.
you play with wasd with your left hand and jkl with the right.

I will try to change them in hopes that the experience will improve.

so far the game is a somewhat above average but not "great", pizza tower was better.


also one thing that I dislike are the "flying small boxes". you have to time your jumps and attacks perfectly or else you will destroy them without jumping to the next one and you will need to go back to your saving point in order to get the collectible.
this level design makes looking for collectibles feel not so fun.
different thing to make the collectible "hard to get" and different to make it "punishing if you try and fail to get".

ワリオランドライクのハイスピードアクションゲーム。
似たゲームとしてはPizza Towerが挙げられるが、こちらはよりワリオランドアドバンスっぽい印象を受けた。GBAのゲームっぽい見た目だし、随所で流れるSEも明らかにインスパイア元を意識している。

◆ ダイナミックなアクション
「破壊」をテーマにしているだけあって、とにかく豪快に物を壊しながら進んでいけるのが楽しい。主人公アントンの挙動には癖があるが、慣れてくるとハンマーで跳ねながら進んでいくのが楽しくなる。
本家ワリオさながらのアクションの多彩さを見せてくれるのも飽きさせなくて良いポイント。急にドンキーのロケットバレルみたいなアクションも始まったりする。

ただゲームスピードの早さに対して1画面に映る情報が少ないので、どうしても見てから回避が間に合わない場面があるのが難点。慎重に行けば良いのかもしれないが、そうすると爽快感が失われてしまう。
結果として死に覚えゲーっぽさが出てしまっているのは否めないと思った。

まんまワリオランドアドバンスを意識したかの様な見た目で、アニメーションパターンは豊富で演出もド派手。意味無いぐらい画面が爆発するのもかなり面白い。
死亡アニメーションもわざわざ複数用意されており、制作陣の拘り様が随所から感じられて良かった。脱出BGMも熱くて気分を盛り上げてくれる。

ゲームを起動するとすぐ分かる通り、とにかく 。
登場キャラは何かに付けて叫ぶし、何の意味もない"叫ぶ"ボタンまで存在している。

ショップには帽子などのアクセサリーが売っているが、というどうでも良い効果だったりする。
こういう自由なノリに面食らう事もあるが…他の真面目なゲームではなかなか得られない体験で個人的には良かった。

癖はあるしまだ日本語訳がされていないので万人にはオススメし難いが、ゲームのクオリティは間違いなく高い。
爽快で豪快なアクションゲームを求めているなら是非遊んでみて欲しい。

This game is what I wished Pizza Tower was back when it came out. Something about it just didn't click with me, probably how it was hyperfixated on having "good runs" on every level and grading everything you do (& also not a fan of the MS Paint artstyle and the fanbase of <= 12-year-old brainrots). Antonblast feels much closer to its Wario Land 4 origins, not just with its visuals and feelings, but level design too.

The music is PHENOMENAL. The humor is QUIRKY. Everything is EDGY and BADASS in the good kind of way!

My only gripe is the lack of things to do after beating the game. Sure, you can hunt for all the collectables and there are two alternative gamemodes, but when you get good enough to memorize level layout and boss attack patterns, it leaves me wishing for something more.

Despite that, Antonblast is worth every penny. Buy it. Endorse it. Bust your balls while trying to no-hit-run the bosses. It's the true successor to the best platformer game ever made. Even just getting to experience all the levels for the first time is a fantastic experience, and slowly overcoming the toughest bosses is satisfying.

Sin dudas el mejor juego del 2024 para mi, excelente trabajo a todos los responsables de crear esta joya.

I don't really post reviews, but I wanted to throw in my contribution.

So I've been following this game while it was in development, about over a year ago or so when they dropped one of the first demos. The game has come a long way since then and I'm happy to say it was worth the wait. To be honest, this is probably one of the most fun games I've played in a while, and I say this as somebody who isn't huge into platformers.

The gameplay is fast, it feels great to play and it's especially fun going through levels quickly and destroying so much in your path. The levels so far have all been fun to play through, not a single level so far that has made me feel frustrated unlike most platformers I'd say. Not to mention that all of the bosses I've seen have been pretty unique to fight against.

The levels each have had their own unique mechanics, enemies and aesthetics to them. It's been keeping things fresh and unexpected going into the next one.

Art style, music, sound design, and all the other small things have been really good as well. My only nitpicks are that sometimes it can be a little difficult to tell whats going on, and I'm not the biggest fan of some of the dialogue.

A very solid 9/10 game. These guys have clearly poured their hearts into making AntonBlast and I hope they see huge success.

One of the most fun platformers I've ever played. Dying is fair, characters are fun and enjoyable to watch, art and music is fantastic, voice acting goes above and beyond. Anton Blast is completely oozing with charm and I hope to see more content made for Anton Blast/Anton in general in the future

Incredible late 90s-early 00s spirit in this game: huge What-a-Cartoon art and sound direction, hi-fi GBA visuals, PSX-era platforming rudeness and marketing crudeness, and a bunch of shoutouts to Pretty Hate Machine.

A lot of the stuff other people consider to be cons are things I enjoy, like the visual overstimulation and willingness to ♥♥♥♥ the player up with brutal difficulty later in the game. I disagree with the sentiment that the controls are "sloppy". The game is plenty responsive, it just revolves around momentum and buffering inputs so if you screw up you're likely to keep screwing up until you calm down and reset.

I think between that and the sheer amount of stuff going on people wind up losing track of what's going on and feeling a lack of control. "Takes getting used to" isn't an automatic con for me. I got used to it, I have a taste for it. It's good that it's like this.

There *is* stuff I'd call ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, like a specific enemy being hidden behind a foreground element in Concrete Jungle, or generally the physics and clipping issues with Pinball Mire, but that A. isn't terribly common and B. doesn't stem from the game's core philosophy, so it could be fixed. The devs are currently patching the game to sand off rough edges like that.

But no, the game is just willing to get mean and rude to teach you things. You can draw parallels between the 1st miniboss and Pepperman in Pizza Tower for how they beat you into controlling your character better instead of mindlessly charging forward, for example. And it gets *tough* in the final act, a lot tougher than Pizza Tower.

Excited for more from Summitsphere, kinda super hope they make a Wario Land 3-like with this skeleton.

ついにantonblastが配信したので
配信日で購入してダウンロードし
早速プレイしています！
去年で発売予定だが延期となり、
今年の11月で発売かと思いきや、
さらに延期になってしまいましたが、
12月4日にて何事もなく無事に
配信しました。
pizza towerに続き、
antonblastも気になり、
発売までは体験版も
よくプレイしていました。

まだ公式で確認とってはおりませんが、
steam deckでプレイしております。
最後までプレイした所、
問題なさそうです。

まず結論から言わせると、
最高に面白い！
こちらの作品もワリオランドアドバンスに
インスパイアされたゲームとなり、
行きと帰りシステムが搭載している
アクションゲームです！
さらにクラッシュバンディクーに
インスパイアされてるところもあります！
この先は良かった所などを上げていきます。

[良かった所]
・ダイナミックなアクションが楽しい。
・制限時間内の脱出パートが楽しい。
・BGMがカッコよくて最高。
・お楽しみ要素あり。
・ボスバトルが熱い。

・ダイナミックなアクションが楽しい。
今回のゲームは
ワリオ✖︎クラッシュバンディクーのような感じのアクションゲーム。
タイトル通りだが、
とにかく爆発が多くダイナミックが感じます。
アクションも面白い！
画面も揺れるくらいです。
(※ちなみに設定で画面を揺らさないように
することが可能。)
ゲームの難易度は高いと思います。
pizza towerとは異なり体力制付きです。
体力がなくなるとミスになり、
ステージの最初または中間地点から
やり直しになります。
また、ポーズからやり直しも可能。
ちなみに
ミスをすると特別な「死に様」があり、
体力が残り一つの時に当たると、
ユニークな死に様が出ます。
例えば大きな柱に潰される死に様など。
これは面白いと感じました。
ちなみにグロテスクになる所はないかと思います。
なお、
何回ミスしてもゲームオーバーは無し。

・制限時間内の脱出パートが楽しい。
ステージの最後にある起爆スイッチを押すと、
It's Happy Hour !
制限時間内に脱出するところが面白い！
脱出時は、
もちろんステージが変化するので、
行きとは別の楽しみ方があり最高です。

・BGMがカッコよくて最高。
ステージやボスのテーマなどを聞いてみて、カッコ良くて最高でした！
特に「It's Happy Hour」が
一番最高と言えるでしょう！

・お楽しみ要素あり。
一度クリアしたステージに入ると、
2つのモードが解禁されます。
そのモードの他にもアイテム探しもあり、
こう言ったお楽しみ要素が
含まれているのは非常に良い。

・ボスバトルも熱い！
ボスは強めですが
それでも熱いバトルでした。
どのゲームもそうですが、
ただに単に攻撃をするだけでなく、
ボスの攻撃も読むことがポイント。
強いボスもいますが、
それでも熱いバトルで最高に楽しかった！

[気になったところ]
これに関しては特にないかと思います。
あとは人それぞれになるかと思います。

他のレビューでもおっしゃる通り、
今作は言語が英語のみであり、
キャラのセリフや操作説明など
全て英語です。
つまり、日本語は対応していない。
こちらは最初から知っていたので、
問題ないかと。
そこは仕方がないところですが、
RPGではなくアクションゲームなので、
あまり読めなくても楽しめるかと思います！
操作説明はイラストみたいなのがあるので、何とかなるかと。
今作にはアイテム屋があり、
その場所でも説明文が英語になっておりますが、見た目で分かるアイテムがありますので、その辺もなんとかなると思います！

色々書きましたが、
anton blastもpizza towerと同様、
難易度は高めだけど、
最高傑作なゲームでした！
こちらもオススメできるゲームだと
感じます！

Was an early backer for this on kickstarter. It was absolutely worth the money and having played it I'm kicking myself for not giving them even more money, what a stellar game. Not a single bad level or boss fight. Lean, incredibly well designed action platformer.

Just beat the game. Felt mixed about it at first, mainly because of the health mechanics. I didn't like it because it kept me from going fast. Then I realized, I have skill issue.

Anyways the level design in this game is very clever, The bosses are really fun, too. Though I did feel there were some points in the game where it wasn't communicated what I was supposed to do well enough.

Honestly I feel really bad writting a negative review for this game since I know the dev team probably put alot of work into this project, but if I'm being completely honest I feel like I've been trying to force myself to like this game when in reality from the start I could tell I wan't really going to like this game.

The game feels to slow, controling Anton feels clunky sometimes, The bosses are just complete visual overloads that overwhelm me because of all the flashing and screen shaking which causes me to lose track of Anton and die and I felt unhappy and frustrated with at least one thing coming out of a level which caused me to just have a very negative experience with the game since I wasn't really having fun with it.

Overall the music, visuals, animations ect are all really good but I just didn't have fun playing it and was planning on finishing it before posting this review but I was just to frustrated to do so.

This is the type of game that you can tell the devs had a lot of fun making. There were so many cool things and level concepts and scenarios that caught me off guard. I love the art style and animation, and the music is really good, and the gameplay is really satisfying and fun. There were many times where I lost track of where Anton was on the screen, and some bosses had moments where I was like, "there's so much stuff happening, how am I expected to dodge this?" But it was never enough to annoy me or dislike the game or anything.

There's so much weird cool dumb stuff in it, like the cowboy hat and shutter shades, the "funny" tv, the one tiny devil thing in the glasshouse level that says "don't screw up! Don't choke!" The music tapes, the scream button. Stuff that feels like the devs were just goofing off, yknow. And the way everything is presented, the spectacle of it all, it really shows that the devs loved what they were making, and I gotta say, the love is infectious. Antonblast supero bastante mis expectativas, si te gusta los juegos de acción, caóticos, de Wario Land y plataformeo este juego es para tí.
El juego es muy creativo y muy adictivo. Constantemente estarás rompiendo cosas, matando enemigos y impactado de todo lo que te ofrece este titulo, por ende quiero destacar algunas cosas de este:.

COSAS DESTACABLES:

1. ESTILO GRÁFICO: El juego toma de inspiración sobre muchos juegos de la Game boy advance, cosa que me encanta, parece que estas jugando desde esa consola. Los sprites estan muy bien trabajados, llamativos e interesantes y los usan de muy buena manera, hay escenas asombrosas usando simplemente pixels. ¡Bien hecho!

2. JEFES : Cuphead ¿Quién te conoce? ¡LOS JEFES SON UNA PTA MARAVILLA! SON INCREÍBLES.
Son un espectáculo, la forma que te atacan, las diversas maneras con las que debes derrotarlos y sobre todo el carisma que tienen estos. Bien hecho. Te recomiendo ver gameplays de los jefes.

3. NIVELES: Hay niveles que me gustaron mucho, son muy creativos como Bomb Candy Mines, su apartado visual, la mecanica de la bomba y el escape son elementos destacados de este nivel o como Concrete Jungle, su música es increible, los enemigos, la verticalidad de esta y sus mecánicas.

4. PERSONAJES: Los personajes son muy carismaticos, todos tienen su personalidades que más de alguna sonrisa te sacaran, sobre todo Satan, Annie y los mini demonios. Estos ultimos son uno de mis favoritos, espero que traduzcan el juego a otros idiomas...

5. NIVELES: Los niveles tienen diversas maneras de pasarlos y ambas tienen su única forma. ¿Jugar pinball para pasarlo? ¿Escapar de un robot gigante para regresar? ESTO ES GENIAL aunque hay algunos medio raros como the Big Bath que literalmente son backrooms, pero bueno. Ademas el juego sigue la misma formula de Pizza tower, llegar al final y luego regresar a la entrada para completarlo. Si, no puede ser original, pero huir de los niveles son la mejor parte de estos. This is peak video game. Don't be fooled, this isn't even close to a Pizza Tower clone. This takes inspiration from Wario Land and Crash Bandicoot. It's probably not a game for everyone, since it's pretty challenging, especially the bosses and the final level. But if you like Wario Land or Crash Bandicoot, buy this on the spot. Peak puzzle platformer, the developers cooked so well they're world-class chefs.

Not really a fan, sadly.

The levels are doable but oddly quite long and poorly paced. I feel a huge chunk of development likely took place in the first level, as it feels a whole lot more polished than pretty much everything after it. The “Wario-Land-4-approach” to levels, having an escape, also does not feel as thought-out and integrated into the level design as it could have. Having longer levels means you have to raise the time limit for the return, which makes mistakes along the way feel more impactful and as though there almost isn’t even a need for a timer anymore.

That said, it feels as though checkpoints were a quick-and-dirty fix to the difficulty. Instead of retouching the length of levels, let’s just make it so the player doesn’t have to restart from the very beginning if he screws up. Over time, this dampens the sense of punishment of messing up, driving a player to want to make a full run better, and replaces it with a NEW kind of punishment more akin to, “great, I’m stuck at this point until I figure out what the game wants me to do.”

The move set is a bit polarizing; I think it’s pretty interesting, but it has its quirks I can’t get behind. The bouncing is the biggest of these. If the player touches the spin button again at all when he’s already in a spin, he HAS TO wait for another bounce to complete. As far as I could tell, there’s no cancellation. This is one of a few choices with the controls I found pretty frustrating for a game with fast-paced escape sequences.

The game has a lot of personality, especially in its visuals, but the referential bits don’t let you forget at any moment, “hey, did you know this is supposed to be a Wario game? Did you remember that?” The audio design (soundfonts and character quips,) character’s poses and actions, names of alternate colors, “Keyzer-clones” in every level— the game would feel a lot more interesting if it didn’t force itself into the shadow of Wario Land games, and, instead, leaned into the unique personality that it DOES most certainly have otherwise. Being inspired is fine; intentionally trying to be an obsessive, gushing fan letter is not. I.e. The IP just needs to be itself.

Bit of a warning, this game is NOT EASY. It's a much different experience than Pizza Tower and you might find yourself having to repeat a boss or a section of a level multiple times. However, the game will add checkpoints frequently in every level, as well as on boss stages. Check the "hard" section of this review for details.

Gimme the skinny!!
Antonblast is a 2d sidescroller inspired by the Wario Land series of games, particularly Wario Land 4. Get to the end of a level while keeping an eye out for money and secrets. At the end of a level, HAPPY HOUR activates, and you have to rush back before the time runs out. You may choose to play as Dynamite Anton or his coworker Dynamite Annie on their way to get their boozy spirits back from Satan and his crazy zany minions.

This game is an insane balls-to-the-wall experience. It's art design is a huge 90s throwback to zany in-your-face advertising, so it's loud, explosive, and crazy as hell. I cannot stress this enough, it is seriously not for the faint of heart and is not afraid to be explosive and loud with everything. Check the Art section below for more details.

There really is no escaping the similarities. Pizza Tower has developed a much similar concept, and both games have been in development at around the same time. They both have mentioned each other in their respected Discord communities many times, and have a great respect for each other's work. McPig has even drawn Peppino frenching Anton. They're really made for each other.

However, both games play in a completely different fashion, and you may be in a disappointment if you come in with certain expectations.

While Pizza Tower allows for much more freedom of movement and enough breathing room to play how you want, this game's design does not allow for many screw-ups. You're allowed only 3 hits, you can't grab enemies, run up walls, or super jump to the top of the ceiling. Instead, you use your hammer to activate a boost called a CLUTCH, similar to Wario's Shoulder Bash. It's essentially a boost with a short burst, and with enough timing and skill, you can get through a level pretty quickly. You can also increase your jump a little bit by swinging your hammer in the air, then bouncing off of something like the floor or an enemy to give yourself some height and a spinning attack. It will slow you down significantly, but with enough skill, you can combo this spin attack with your boost to absolutely destroy enemies while clutching the hell outta there. You're allowed a health bar and some hearts throughout a level, but with only 3 hits to get through a section (with some minor health pickups), there's not much room for error.

On a normal run, it's pretty fair but tough. It's not Contra Hard Corps, but you will get your ass whopped if you're not ready. There's not a lot of modern conveniences either, so if you're a die-hard retro fan, you might have some fun with this.

This game is not afraid to throw things at you, cluttering up the screen with fun 90s nonsense. It's very reminiscent of an old-school Sega Genesis game: only 3 usable buttons with a simple gameplay loop and a ton of flashy explosions. It's great, but there are definitely moments where levels go on too long, or the camera shake gets in the way of something important. The game can definitely feel bloated with its design, and I really don't blame you if you need to take a break from even just one level. You can reduce this by turning off screen shake in the options menu.

You don't need anything from a level after beating it, not even a spirit. That means that secrets and money are not required (though money can really help and make the game easier). However, there are three ways to play a level after you beat it (Arcade, Combo, Time Trial), so there is more than enough replay value if you want to go for 100%. The camera can also feel like it's zoomed-in a bit too much, but if you know the level layout, it won't be too much of an issue.

The art is funking fantastic, and whoever is responsible for the art direction deserves massive props. It's extreme and urban in the best way, and I can definitely see this as proper graffiti. As opposed to improper graffiti, I guess. Very reminiscent of Sega Genesis and it's extreme in-your-face marketing that the 90s was known for. Even their trailers and teasers were on-point, with some guy yelling SUMMIT at the end of every video.

For the first few levels, it's a blast, and the spectacle isn't much of a problem. As the game goes on however, it feels as though they try to mash as much stuff in every level. There's not really a set rule on how long a level can go. So you'll be on a level in what feels like forever as you're getting explosions and enemies thrown at you from what feels like every angle. It can very easily feel overwhelming if you're not used to a game like this. I highly recommend either playing it in a window or turning screen shake off if it becomes too much. Playing this on Steam Deck on a tiny screen makes it feel much more enjoyable manageable to the senses, even with screen shake on. I'm sure the upcoming Switch version will also feel great on a handheld like that.

Even in long levels, it seems like the game does everything in its power to give you a fair chance. There are multiple checkpoints and clear indicators, even on long bosses with multiple phases. But even then it feels like it's too much. Sometimes I'm begging a level end just to take a little break and absorb what I've just played. I feel like there is definitely a pacing issue in this game, but I don't know. It can be hard to critique a game and tell it to "tone it down" when it's meant to be in-your-face from the very beginning. Maybe I'm getting senile after my thirty years on this planet.

I will say that after playing through everything, it's very fun to replay once I know what to expect. And with three ways to runback a level, they can be very enjoyable. I will also say that if you're of the Zoom variety of human beings, you will probably enjoy this game very much. I do not like that new Habbo Hotel on Amazon Prime, but if you're one of those Z-boys who love stuff like that, this may be up your alley.

Despite all my whining about Anton coming in and shaking my head around, this game is a great spectacle and a proper Wariolike with tons to offer. It's not for everyone: it can be a bit difficult and very flashy, but if any part of the previews makes you go "WOWWIE I GOTTA TRY THAT RIGHT NOW", then this is most definitely the game for you.

I backed this game on Kickstarter, and had been following its development ever since. After putting 13 hours into it, and completing the campaign, I wish I could of thrown more money at it.

Lets not beat around the bush, Antonblast is freaking MARVELOUS! As a big fan of 2D Platformers, this is one you should not pass up.

Its funny, its challenging, its visually a treat, the music and sound design gets your blood pumping! I love a game that can give me a good time while also kick me in the nuts. It wears its inspirations on its shoulders and I love every moment of it.

The hellish combination of Crash Bandicoot, Cow & Chicken, Beavis and Butthead, Wario Land and a few other things had no business working this freaking good, man.

Of course it goes without saying there are a few things I didn't click with at first, but the power of trial and error came through in the end. I appreciate how well collectables are hidden, incentivizing me to go back and replay levels. It was also exhilarating getting better at running through and learning the gimmicks the game throws at you. Comes in handy by the endgame, tho I hope the final level does see a few revisions with how punishing it can be at times. That is only a small nitpick tho to the really well made difficulty curve.

Bosses for me personally are a big highlight of this game. Usually bosses in 2D games run the gambit of being too easy, or not very interesting. The Bosses in Antonblast feel like actual FIGHTS. Being able to damage the bosses at all times while they're doing just as much to attack you is fantastic! Usually ending with a triumphant spectacle! Big props to the team for sure!

Another year, another excellent Wario Land inspired platformer.

Antonblast takes the garlic-enjoyer genre to the next level by refining the traditional platforming and injecting it with a ton of style. The angular designs and snappy animation makes the game really stand out. The soundtrack is also full of great sample-heavy songs.

While it's development buddy Pizza Tower took some influence from Sonic's speedy perfect level runs, Anton takes inspiration from Crash's destructive goofy platforming. Twinsanity is clearly a favorite as seen by Anton's fun wacky tone and one standout song on the soundtrack.

Antonblast is as much of a lover letter to Crash as it is to Wario, but of course it carves out it's own style to become a fun destructive platformer.
backed this game on kickstarter and it's been genuinely insane to see the game improve so much over the years. an absolute must if you love 2d platformers (and wario land-likes)

A beautiful love letter to tough-as-nails platformers. Both the art style and the gameplay are wonders on the senses and leave you wanting for more after you beat the final boss. Though the game is...relatively short (12 levels and 7 bosses, each representing the 7 deadly sins.), no level truly felt like a filler! Each level had a unique gimmick, and some of them even had a special escape sequence! Seriously, the bath level is so awesome.

Though the game isn't without flaws, sometimes clashing art styles stick out. It's not the weird 3D effect on very few characters, but rather smaller things, like the little dog when you break a checkpoint, and the spray can look like a placeholder texture. its not something that ruins the experience but i felt like it could have been done better. Cutscenes also tend to look a bit...Stiff? Though it works to display the awkwardness of these characters just like the certain design choices. Sometimes, it just looks a bit off. Though this strangeness double works to the game's benefit to show that these characters are just awkward drunks, and though the cutscenes look stiff, the gameplay animations are far from looking bad. Speaking on top of gameplay the difficulty spikes are ROUGH. i feel like at times i would be throwing myself at the wall to either solve a collectible puzzle or beat a room/boss. not to mention some of the challenges feel counterintuitive. Yes, Antonblast devs i know you love your box/enemy jumps but can we PLEASE not use it so often? even worse that they don't respawn. though, of course, there are ways to counteract this punishing nature of the game, and that is to buy hearts. I'm so happy this game has a shop because one thing i noticed in Pizza Tower. A similarly great game that takes inspiration from the same source. is that all the money and score you collect in that game amounts too well...Nothing! you use it to unlock boss doors and eventually toss it back to get an...alright skin. in Anton's, you can buy buffs, cosmetics, and permanent health upgrades! i like that! it makes me feel like actually scoring better can lead to an easier time.

though back on the critiques, this game is funny; it has some random memes that will catch you off guard, and honestly, I'm all for it. If you want a fun time where the developers put in their time and love of the genre into every facet of the game

However, a thing to note before you buy this product is to try not to compare Pizza Tower to Antonblast. though they are very alike, these are definitely two different experiences, and one is SIGNIFICANTLY HARDER. Like most indie darlings GO INTO THIS GAME AS BLIND AS POSSIBLE. i HATE how every boss in [insert game] spoils probably some of the most surprising boss fights in the game. this game HAS surprises, and your learning about them does pay off. Enjoy the 5-10 hours without looking up anything. it WILL be worth it.

It doesn't sate my perfectionism autism quite like Pizza Tower, but it makes up for that in style, panache, personality, and an immutably memorable experience. I'm still in the middle of playing and I already know that I'm going to be coming back to this one just like Pizza Tower.

Where Pizza Tower has an overwhelming Wario World vibe where the goal is to collect your friends and then get out a'la Wario Land 4, ANTONBLAST goes all-in on the Wario Land 4 energy with an included movement mechanic that rewards memorization and precision. Literally none of its escape sequences so far have been anything short of creative and invigorating. It invests in this style so much that the art also seems to take pointers from it.

If this were the future of games, I would become much more heavily invested. The art is filled with life and detail despite the cel-shaded style, filled with aggressively asymmetric shapes to lend towards the air of chaos and mayhem that this game advertises itself on. It chooses to work with the audience that Pizza Tower created and keep their attention. That it stands on its own and is different enough to avoid comparison removes any anxieties I might have had going in.

Also, being designed in this low-fidelity style means that you can gift this to a friend that has a potato calling itself a computer. I could probably play this on my old Windows XP machine from 2008 if it didn't state Windows 8 in the requirements.

Look, just get it. The asking price is steep for an indie game, but it's also much more lively and memorable than some AAA game experiences have been lately.

Honestly? Everything I was hoping for out of this game.
While I don't have the skills nor time required to 100% the entire thing, much less get CRACKED on every stage, the game itself was, from start to finish, an adrenaline filled love letter to Wario Land 4 (And to a somewhat lesser extent, Crash) fans.

The artstyle's downright DELICIOUS, with bright colors and sharp angles everywhere to really sell that gritty vibe the game's aiming for. They really nail the whole "This could be a Gameboy Advance title" feeling with the cutscenes and way the sprites move, as well.
The music slaps so hard, and I can't think of a single stage or boss theme that I didn't thoroughly enjoy, from start to finish. (Can't wait for the official OST to release, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.)
The transformations are ALMOST all incredibly fun, unique, and simply wonderful to use (looking at you, jetpack...) and they REALLY capture the "Wario Land" vibe of what makes a transformation great.
The game simply feels GOOD to play. Clutching, dashing, bouncing, and rolling your way through the stages feels *wonderful* once you get the hang of it. The control of it all takes a little bit to really get down, but once you do, it REALLY clicks into place.
The bosses in the later half of the game took some warming up to, but really? They're perfect for the game's overall control and vibe. As mentioned above, all their music is divine, and while your first run-through with them might be "Oh GOD what the ♥♥♥♥ is happening!?" due to the chaotic nature, once you understand it, MAN are they fun to fight.

And, of course, on top of ALL of this, the Devil himself is voiced by none other than Gianni Matragrano, and he REALLY makes the character come to life.

If you're even remotely a fan of the Wario Land titles, ESPECIALLY 4...


It is MORE than worth the money, you won't regret it.

Antonblast is a pure platforming masterpiece. This is easily my GOTY.
Wario Land and Crash Bandicoot are two of my all-time favorite platforming franchises, so to see a game like this so proudly be inspired by them (as well as bring its own unique, manic energy) is an easy way into my heart. It plays like a whirlwind of destruction, feels like it, and SOUNDS like it too (oh lord that soundtrack). Every level, enemy and boss is memorable and there is barely a single dull moment--the game is bursting with attitude in every way from start to finish. Even if you get mad at a hard or frustrating part, you'll always wanna try again to see what's next.
And yes, the game has plenty of collectibles and challenges to overcome so there is absolutely no shortage of things to do in the game, you're getting your damn money's worth.

So why are you still holding onto that money of yours? Pick it up now, pick up on sale, get someone to pick it up for you. No matter how you pick it up, just... pick it up.
Pick it up... and

After playing through the first three or so levels, I have to say this game is a hidden gem for 2024. The gameplay is fantastic, melding different inspirations (Wario Land, Sonic, Pizza Tower, etc) masterfully. I have a hard time recommending this game because I can't really say I enjoyed what I played of it. I got to around level 6 or so - past the first set of levels - and in the end I just felt mixed.

The game is energetic, spastic, funny, and a visual/auditory joy to experience. It's also a nightmare to tell what's going on at times. The gameplay be fast, frantic, explosive, and enjoyable, but other times it can be frustrating, confusing, and annoying. I just kept going from "I'm having fun" to "I'm not having fun" constantly.

First off, the game is a treat to look at artistically. I love the character designs, enemy designs, and levels. The music also slaps (no complaints about the music at all). The game is so caught up in its explosive art though that it makes it tough to play at times.

This is a game in 2024 where I actively complained about the to myself - which I don't think I've done since I played a GBA port of a game. Constantly there are times throughout the game where I felt I couldn't react to a jump, enemy, obstacle, etc, because the screen is simply too zoomed in. Also, because it's so zoomed in the game's graphics feel insanely difficult to parse at times. I like the pixelated look, but blown up on a 1440p screen it feels like I'm looking at an emulated GBA game (which may have been the point tbh). This makes the pixelated art style REALLY hard to read for me personally, and kind of ruins a little bit of the charm. I wish there were some AA, filter, or CRT options in the game to try because I think they'd help with the parsing issue a little bit for me.

I lost where Anton & Annie were all of the time. Often times I'll hit some blocks or an enemy and have to stand around for a half second just to check where I'm at, or risk running into something. The foreground gets in the way during the sections where you jump into the background so much it felt like I had hair in my eyes during them. Anton & Annie flash white when you're spinning around with their weapons making them surprisingly difficult to see whenever you hit literally anything. This combined with the previously mentioned screen crunch and the effects that pop up when you hit things leads to an experience that feels like it wants me to go fast but fights me at every turn visually. I feel like if I wanted to go fast I'd have to memorize the game, which at that point I may as well be a TAS bot if I'm just going to memorize inputs to get through something safely.

The game is absolutely stunning visually, but damn does it make it difficult to play for me. I think all of these problems/nitpicks could be fixed with a patch though. Add an accessibility option to highlight Anton/Annie with a thick black outline or to always keep them in front of the effects and I think most of my complaints will be a non issue.

Gameplay wise, I do , but the visual chaos brings down the gameplay with it. As mentioned, I often felt like I wanted to go fast but HAD to go slow constantly. Hitting enemies from landing would sometimes just launch me up in the air because the attack button also bounces you upwards if done in the air, and the timing is pretty generous for it. Anton/Annie have a surprising amount of inertia as well, meaning you often times will drift slightly too far or too short of where you wanted to land and have to try a few extra times. This isn't a problem most of the time, but the game often has little secrets and such that require you to bounce off boxes successfully, or repeat the entire level to try again. There are also times where you simply feel out of control of the characters. I wouldn't mind a "try to get through a level perfectly" sort of thing, but as far as I'm aware there isn't actually a prize or anything for it, so there isn't a point other than for self satisfaction (this could be user error here, maybe there is something and I just don't know). There's just a LOT of minor gameplay annoyances that I think you'll really feel if you're more familiar with platformers. If you're not, you'll probably only feel the screen crunch. I really enjoy the speed of the game, and I enjoy the general ideas at play here, but often times I found myself annoyed more than having fun.

I really enjoy the chaos and destructiveness of the gameplay, but I feel so out of control sometimes that it backfires and I stop enjoying it as much. TBH all I can really summarize it as is "I feel mixed". I love hitting things, but I also hate how I bounce around like a rubber ball. I love dashing through enemies, but I hate that I can barely see myself after hitting one, so I mash attack and bounce accidentally, or get hit. I love the impact effects, but I can't see anything. It's just a constant back and forth for me.

A quick word on the bosses, I just kind of found them annoying. I ran into two of them. The game is split into (minor structure spoiler) . The first boss I ran into was funny looking, but I constantly felt like I was getting caught by attacks that I reacted to. I felt like I had to give the boss a crazy amount of room or I'd just get locked into a command grab from smash bros. The hitboxes just felt a bit off. The second boss I ran into was, simply put, a cluster ♥♥♥♥. Just constantly smacking the hell out of him while enemies that felt like they didn't belong showed up. I enjoyed the second half of the boss a bit better, but I still found myself annoyed. The bosses look cool, are tough, but a bit frustrating.

There's also a LOT of little QoL annoyances. I bought the hat for example and legit thought my game was busted for around 10-20 minutes because of the weird black border at the top. It was kind of funny when I realized it, but I was more disappointed like "oh, I just wasted all of that money, and I don't get an actual hat" more than "ha, that's a funny joke". The disappointment left me assuming that all the other items like it would do something dumb to the screen as a bit - meaning they all were worthless in my head now. I bought the TV as well, and it felt like a waste of my in game cash. I don't mind little decorations and jokes, I ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ love decorating, but I guess I was just annoyed that these things were so useless for the cost (maybe they're cooler later).

The additional skins also are in a vertical linear list of like 50-100 items (I don't remember the exact number) which means you've gotta SCROLL to find the one you might want.

Levels are scattered everywhere with no indicators of where they're at other than memory and the initial black fog. This led to me getting a bit lost when I'd look away for a moment after beating a level and not know where the new level just opened up. If you want to change characters or costumes you also have to run back to the doors at the every time - which isn't the worst but it's also just kind of a time waster.

Last pedantic complaint, I think one of the rooms you unlock after the first boss is a kickstarter backer avatar area or something? It's huge, I didn't know wtf it was when I was in it (still don't), and it just felt strangely out of place (and glitchy). I don't mind showing off who backed your game, but I was just left a bit confused after finding it - and dissapointed because it wasn't anything substantial for me.

Overall, I'm just mixed on the game. I like the visuals, gameplay, and music, but there's so many little things adding up to annoy me that it's difficult for me to say I enjoyed it. I refunded the game and plan on buying it after a few patches on a sale, I would personally recommend you wait for a few patches as well. A of my issues can be fixed with patches and would easily flip over to positive if done.

I've always been a platformer fan. When I saw this game's kickstarter trailer, I was extremely excited. I played every demo from this game and every time the game became better and better. Now that the final product is out, I gotta say, this is a blast!
Bombastic soundtrack, wacky and fluid spritework and animation, amazing level design, and fun gameplay! This game has everything an action platformer should have.

But the game is far from perfect!

1. The sheer chaos: I love some chaos, don't get me wrong, but to the point that I don't understand whats happening on screen, and then getting punished for it is frustrating. This is especially obvious with the ball transformation. You just explode so much and dash way to fast to the point that its hard to follow even where I'm at. This is also a problem in boss level, especially the main bosses and final boss. They occupy so much space on the screen and have so many flashy attacks, I just get lost in the chaos.

2. The levels: Every level is fantastic and fresh, but they go for so long, especially the hell levels. I don't know if this is a skill issue, but Hell Manor took me an hour and a half to BEAT. I'd rather if a game had small memorable levels, rather than long and tedious levels. I kept having that feeling where I would get bored of a level and couldn't wait to finish it so I can move on to the next one. This is also a problem when it comes to Cracking levels. If I had to restart a level every time my combo ended, I think I would end up in a mental hospital in like 2 weeks. So yeah, I'm not completing this game

3. The platforming: The game is bombastic and speedy, but the areas where I need to slow down and do some tight platforming are so infuriating. Anton and Annie don't have the best air control and their jumps feel heavy, so even tough this game is a platformer, its clear that the duo weren't made for jumping (especially in the Crash Bandicoot crate jumping areas).


In conclusion: This game is clearly made for hardcore platformer lovers and its a clear love letter to some old-school platformer franchises like Crash Bandicoot and Wario Land, and its safe to say that this game isn't for everyone. But this game clearly is a polished, action-packed, bombastic adventure trough and trough.

When I first played Antonball Deluxe, I was enticed and entranced by the iconic "Paul" character, his no-nonsense attitude alongside his iconic sprite work make it a delight to play as him. In Antonblast, I panicked as I hastily scoured the lobby area in an attempt to find Paul, but when I finally played the first level, that's when I found him.

His iconic appearance in Antonblast is a highlight of the game, and it pays awesome homage to the classics, showing that even triple AAA developers like Summitsphere still care about their fans and appreciate the classics as much as we do. Thank you, Paul!

The game is only good for the first 3 levels (ignoring the first boss fight.) The demos' levels were the best parts of the final game. The rest of the game has very boring level design, and the camera constantly makes you run into things that make you take damage. It was a struggle to get through the last 3 levels because they were some of the least fun platforming levels I've ever played in a game.
Anton's movement is also consistently slippery, making it incredibly ridiculous when they expect you to do perfect precise platforming in the middle of a run where you have to constantly spam the "keep running" button on time or else you lose all speed. The game would be like 20% better if running was a toggle, or the dash button just made you keep running until you stopped holding the direction key.
The bosses are the worst part of the game, with them all essentially being the strategy of just memorizing their attacks and then tanking whatever damage you just can't bother with anymore. Many, especially the final boss, also last for far too long than necessary, which seems to be an attempt at making them more climactic but just makes them go on long after the boss has lost its novelty.
The game is also incredibly cluttered. There are so many particles, projectiles, and random clusters of enemies all on screen at once. At some point, you just get tired of running through it all and taking damage you can't see in time to where you just start going through each level as mindlessly as possible because it's just too overwhelming to handle.
The controls are also very frustrating to deal with because the "hammer attack" button. The same button to do your dash is the same button to do the hammer spin. This makes the mistake of accidentally spinning when trying to dash while landing far too common to be seen as something the developers couldn't have noticed in playtesting.
Of course, everything besides what I've mentioned is great. The art style is charming, the soundtrack is alright, and the story is pretty funny. However, the gameplay itself is so annoying to play that I wish I didn't try to stick it out to the end to form my opinion because maybe I could have gotten a refund. I don't recommend this game at all. Instead of buying, just go watch some "All Cutscenes" video on youtube to save your time, money, and smile on your face.

A platformer with fantastic presentation and controls that is unfortunately held back by a few level design issues and gimmicks. A small change that I feel would greatly improve the game is if it had a variable camera that would pan in and pan out depending on the room, as sometimes it has that Sonic the Hedgehog issue where you run into an upcoming obstacle before you have a chance to react to it.

I really feel the need to explain how much this game means to me, it's a game I've had my eyes on since the first Kickstarter demo. Hell whenever I finally got my laptop and my Steam account the Dynamite Demo was the first thing I installed on it, and while I understood why... I was pretty heartbroken by the delay, even if it was only a month... My point is I've waited a long time for the full game and it has (no pun intended) been a blast and has been worth all the wait! Seeing all the new levels not shown in the demos was a huge surprise, and the more I replay all of them the more they grow on me, I'm serious there isn't a bad level in this thing.

I really need to stress that Antonblast is absolutely worth your time, it's got just enough content for a casual player to be left satisfied by it, and enough incentive for the 100% and the speedruns (which I'm currently trying to route.) It's got excellent challenge that will certainly humble those who aren't ready, but it never kicks you so hard you don't want to get up, and alongside it's gameplay comes it's sense of humor which... Frankly is right up my alley, it's certainly not ashamed of who it is and that's the best in my eyes.

My only gripe with Antonblast is that I didn't go in with a clear mind. I wasn't prepared for the new levels and that set me off guard. I felt mixed for a good minute due to both my... admitted post work grogginess, and overall unfamiliarity. Thankfully after another run through (or two) I've learned to love every level and I'm struggling to pick a favorite...

In closing. It's was worth the wait, It's worth your time, It's worth your money, and It's certainly worthy of a drink. It's Happy Hour!

A masterpiece of a platformer, and one of the most deranged (in a good way) games I've ever played.

Almost every single stage is brimming with creativity, fun gimmicks, and unique enemy designs. With an explosive flair to boot, you could classify Antonblast as a "destruction platformer", with a focus on flashy, bombastic visuals and destroying as many obstacles that stand in your path. The simple act of traversal is, in of itself, an explosive power trip. Despite the frantic intensity of Anton's wanton destruction, the controls are surprisingly easy to get used to, and once you're a hour or two into the game, the controls feel silky-smooth and VERY intuitive, I never felt as if my inputs were dropped or that the controls were acting unresponsive.

To top off the wonderful level design, Antonblast has an absolutely STELLAR lineup of boss fights, which are all enjoyable in their own right - the strongest being the 4 World Bosses at the end of each respective world, which I would personally consider some of the best in the platforming genre. The second World Boss in particular (Fourth in the entire lineup) is, quite frankly, stunning, and even once the recency bias settles, it will most likely be one of my favorite platformer bosses of all time. Do be warned, though - some of the later bosses are bullet hells in their own right, and do NOT pull any punches.

Oh, and for the record - the music slaps. Hard. Every track is oozing with flair, and while some songs are certainly more memorable than others, the soundtrack simply never gets old. And to top it all off, the spritework in this game is absolutely BEAUTIFUL, with a 90s Cartoon Network-esque charm that makes the game incredibly appealing to the eyes.

For any fan of fast-paced platformers, and/or those who are particularly big fans of games like Crash Bandicoot, Rayman, Donkey Kong Country, and especially Warioland, this game is an absolute must-play and one of the best indie platformers on the market. 20 Dollarydoos is an absolute bargain.

Note - If you are sensitive to flashing lights, screenshake, the like, there is a photosensitivity mode in the game's settings, and you are given the option to disable screenshake entirely if you so desire.

This game is SO worth the twenty dollars and honestly it deserves more. If you've seen or played Pizza Tower, you may think that ANTONBLAST is some kind of game inspired by Pizza Tower. While being mostly similar in terms of 90's styled cartoony absurdity, ANTONBLAST takes inspiration from Wario Land 4, much like Pizza Tower. This game is very challenging so if you thought Pizza Tower wasn't hard enough, this is for you. It has a great story, amazing gameplay, stunning visuals, an artstyle that keeps on giving, various transformations and/or mechanics that never get boring, and so many collectibles along with a wide variety of color unlockable color palettes. 10/10 indie game.

Now this is peak blasting

I have the same feelings to this game as I do with Sonic Heroes.
Interpret that how you will.

Playing Antonblast is like watching an up-and-coming performer. The act is practiced and well-executed, fumbles a little towards the end but sticks the landing, and ultimately you feel truly blessed to have witnessed it.

The opening act of Antonblast is strong! It's the sort of platforming you've seen before, but it's fast and it hints at small details for those willing to look for it. You don't have to go that deep, what's present at the surface level is entertaining and fully enjoyable! That high energy follows into the first boss battle which - uniquely for platformer bosses - is quite challenging! Pattern recognition is important, and as you try and try again, you get better. And by the end, you don't feel like you were just waiting for the big glowing weakpoint to appear. Okay, maybe you are, but it's an enjoyable "wait".

As Antonblast continues, each level is revealed in spectacular fashion, each has a unique identity and focuses on different mechanics. There are no stinkers in this level pool! And the bosses continue to be just as challenging and memorable! Maybe you want to go back and retry one of those earlier levels now that you've gotten better at hammer jumping? If so, you realize just how well Antonblast has been designed for SPEED. Dash into dash, into hammer jump, into clutch boost... The layers beneath the surface get revealed...

Towards the end, Antonblast begins asking more from you. The levels get longer and the reaction times you need to showcase become tighter. The controls fight back a little. You start dying more and realizing just how vital those checkpoints are. You then remember that there's a time trial and chain mode which involve going through these levels without dying... And then you realize just how often you're dying. By the end, Antonblast's difficulty has skyrocketed and it says if you're not able to meet the challenge, it's time to Get Gud. Mercifully there's adaptive difficulty in places, more checkpoints when your skill is lacking. Antonblast is beatable, and a cathartic experience... But the sheer difficulty spike towards the end - the final boss especially - is staggering.

However, at no point is Antonblast boring. And never does it ask more of you than you can give. If you're willing to practice, learn, and persevere, the challenges can be conquered. And then there are more challenges digging deeper into what the game has to offer. So many things. To those looking to master it, Antonblast has so much that it's willing to share. And it will always be willing to entertain you if you're willing to meet it halfway.

I can't easily recommend Antonblast. There is a skill gate later in (though as of writing the final level is getting some further balancing) so those who aren't great at platformers are going to reach a wall. And even if you are great at speedy platformers there's a lot to perfect. Thus if you're curious about Antonblast, I would highly recommend playing the demo as it has the first two levels. If you have a great time with that, then Antonblast is worth giving a shot. If you think you're going to like Antonblast, then you will love it. It's a tough love though.

Annie needs her own game.

Note: I will not be comparing this game to any other comparable games that came out in, let's just say arbitrarily, January 26th, 2023.

Antonblast is a game I love a lot more than I like.

This is a game that had a relatively short development time and is able to condense a lot of fun, inventive ideas into twelve short levels and nine bosses. The manic gameplay encourages you to fling yourself around without a care in the world and smash everything you come across into teeny-tiny little pieces. The game is at its best when its novelty is on full display.

The game is at its worst when it requires precision.

Antonblast is not nearly as precise as a platformer as it thinks it is. There are very few methods of canceling moves into each other in a manner I'd call graceful, but oftentimes the game and its bosses are designed as if you have precise control over Anton/Annie. Additionally, your clutch attack will often bounce you back, which is not commonly a problem in standard gameplay but is tremendously annoying in certain bosses where attempting to strike a weakpoint will result in you being bounced into an attack.

The game's visual noisiness, while a strong part of its personality, is also a contribution to some issues with the gameplay. I had to turn screen shake off entirely in order to focus on certain attacks and platforming sections. However, the visual noise and general lack of clarity with certain aspects such as invincibility/vulnerability windows means that I'm still not sure when I'm invincible during a hammer jump. There were frequent times where I would be doing a hammer jump and would harmlessly bounce off an enemy, while others times I would take damage without any clear distinction between an enemy's states. Either that, or they would enter the state so quickly that I couldn't adjust properly in time to avoid the attack. This was often an issue during clutches, which I would frequently need to use for mobility purposes, as its hard to stop a clutch once it actually begins.

But I'm being a bit hard on this game, I think. There's a lot to love here. Even the title screen itself, with the game screaming at you, followed by the delightful slapstick opening animation, are able to convey a grimy, late 90's and early 2000's energy that is completely and utterly wonderful to experience firsthand. The game's personality is easily its biggest selling point, and levels are frequently peppered with moments of hilarity that are completely unrelated to the actual gameplay that make me feel like I'm playing a cartoon. The little opening segments with Satan, the moments where Danton randomly appears in a level and you get to kill him, the hilarious imps and their dialogue, and the various setpieces that you frequently destroy as you progress through each level all help make this game a riot.

However, Antonblast is a game I could only play in short blasts--err, bursts. It's hard to get into a flow state with the game and I think the levels should've been designed around your controls better. The inventive gameplay can't quite overcome a slow boiling frustration with controls and hitboxes.

You'll find a nice collection of spirits behind the bar. There's a lot of fun, fruity cocktails, some of the drinks have a real kick, and the guy working the place has a real fun personality. However, I couldn't just sit there and drink all night. Even just three drinks down I'd start noticing the weirdly grimy, bitter taste in the brew, and I'd have to head out mostly sober, which is a real shame.

It must be the satanic aura all around the place...

Oh well. Drink responsibly.

Consider it aas a very brief opinion of mine...

I was extremely excited to finally play the full release of Antonblast after waiting for a month or two.
And I have to say and praise the strongest side it has, which are: its energy, creativity, originality; its artstyle and visuals are amazing, platforming at times fun and challanging, and so are brief puzzles and overall concept of it, being a love letter to WarioLand4, specifically its energy.

However, the issues in question, in my opinion, come down to, generally, style over gameplay, and either that hurricane or smth else made that the game near the end kind of starts to look slightly worse.. ? Like the ending cutscene looking clunky.
Elaborating, from what I have noticed, most of these issues could be fixed easily with just one thing. For example: sometimes the camera moving alongside player and enviroment make it extremely hard to see what is happening and what comes ahead, as one can see in pinball sections in its level. I bet if the camera was fixed to moving up and down these major rooms, instead of alongside player, and was zoomed out, these would be wayyyy better! Plus the platforming is at times very annoying..

Though it does not mean the game is trash nor anything like that. Other than (hot take) 2 last levels, every level is fun, creative and oozes with originality! Especially the pool one, which caught me off guard... and so did every level. Exploring them for first time (and continously dying) was both frustrating and fun!
The visuals are at their best though! Cant really tell a single thing that was done badly, other than final cutscene? Platforming, even though sometimes frustrating, is also engaging and satisfying once you get it all right!
And how could I forget about its humor, probably the most flawless part of this game! It just shows how devs had tons of fun while making this game, which is why I love it!
I always awe experimental games like this one. It just shows how much effort people put into it, and in the end, originality is always welcomed!

Overall, rough around the edges, which is a shame cuz I am fully sure they put everything they could into making this game as best as possible, despite the hurricane!
When it works though it REALLY does!
And seeing the most recent patch that has been added, I think Summit is still polishing their work!

Style, energy and originality is what this game thrives at!
Although style over gameplay is what bit this game a tiny bit in the tail, but if it wasnt for the style, then this game would have been... not Antonblast.

So... yeah, that's all for now!

The visual style has a certain vibe to it that screams "you're gonna wreak some havoc today", and the music is consistently catchy from start to finish.

I do have some small gripes about this game: The difficulty accelerates VERY quickly, but can be managed through trial and error. Also, on the note of difficulty, the game barely gives any semblance of hints as to where collectibles are-- which I do feel could be improved on for completionists like me.

Even still, Antonblast, as a game, proves that it can stand tall among indie video games, and even some of the giants who forged the industry. If you like fast-paced "High Voltage Screaming Action", you'll love this!

ANTONBLAST is an incredible journey from the beginning to the end. A fantastic game at the core, elevated by it's masterful execution.

Every element of the game comes together harmonically, every idea, every obstacle, every part of the level design is crafted carefully to make one of the greatest feeling 2D platformers of all time. The levels reward coming back and looking deeper within, while also being incredible to speed through. The stages have a certain flow to them, which pushes you in the right direction. The secrets are places that feel rewarding to discover, instead of punishing you for not memorising the stage. Completion feels rewarding and not like a chore. The boss fights feel dynamic, as many of them are designed in a way to reward risky moves, allowing you to damage them independently of their attack pattern, instead of just waiting for them to become vulnerable, like the platformer genre has commonly done for years.

Never before have I seen a video game that simultaneously wears it's inspirations so proudly, yet never feeling like it's just referencing something you might remember. It's so creative, so full of passion, every idea is it's own and unique, even if rooted in something that the creators enjoyed.

The sensory stimulation gives an incredible feeling. I don't think I've ever had a game send so many different chemicals to my brain whilst playing. Both on the surface level in the form of visuals and sound design, to the incredible feeling of the gameplay and stage design, which you may not even pay attention to unless you think about it.

I fully recommend ANTONBLAST, it is worth every penny, even at full price. It is one of the greatest 2D platformers of all time.

To get the full experience I would advise looking up videos of the game, as it may spoil you on the many surprises awaiting. Summitsphere did a great job by not showing everything the game has in promotional material and letting the player discover. It keeps you on your toes.

Allow me to make something clear before I start this review:
This game does NOT give you a good first impression. It's surprisingly difficult, and the controls are extremely difficult to get accustomed to. The game also doesn't often do a good job of explaining key mechanics or telegraphing danger, so it can feel like a lot of trial and error.

Overall, it will lead to you getting your ass handed to you easily when you first start playing and it not feeling like your fault 90% of the time. The controls will feel extremely unsatisfying at first.

So if you're extremely impatient and get angry extremely easily, I can't exactly say in good faith that you'll enjoy the experience. And if you're coming into this game having just played Pizza Tower like I was... yeah, you're in for a rough time.

It was such a bad first impression, in fact, that I originally left a strongly-worded negative review on the game and refunded it after playing for only half an hour.

HOWEVER. After re-buying the game (because I had nothing better to do) and gritting through the miserable beginning, I have to say:
... Well, I still don't think the gameplay is great (though I haven't finished the game yet), but I guess it's good enough once you get used to it. Overall, I'd probably still rather play Pizza Tower? But it's a nice change of pace.
And everything else makes up for it.

I know this pun has been said way too much, but this game is genuinely a BLAST! There's so much care put into this game and it's so fun to BLAST your way through levels as fast as possible. But even with that said, if you're coming in here expecting this to play just like Pizza Tower, you've got the wrong idea. They're both similar but Antonblast is closer to Wario Land 4 even though they're both heavily inspired by it. There's some Crash Bandicoot inspiration as well so there's going to be some precise platforming. But that doesn't mean the gameplay is slow. You can still pull things off really fast and show off your speed. The main form of movement called the clutch boost feels awesome to do and combining it with hammer bounces and more makes it even better especially if you pull it off right. There's also many incredible transformations to spice up the gameplay as well. This game is just a BLAST from start to finish and I highly recommend checking it out if you love chaotic speedy fun with a banger soundtrack

If there was such a thing as adrenaline packaged as a game, it's Antonblast. It's legitimately amazing, it's music and level design is some of my favorite stuff from indie games, the characters are all really funny, and like it ticks a huge box of being a shoutout to games nostalgic while also being it's own thing. As a massive Crash Bandicoot fan, I can see how much Tony loves that series, and it shows, but this also stands on it's own, with much more to explore in the levels and how it pushes its presentation in all kinds of good ways.

I'd say this game is not for the faint of heart though, and I'm not talking about the butts and booze. While it is playable to anyone of any skill level (I do not consider myself particularly skilled at games) it will test you and gets hard very fast, but the endorphins you get from beating something hard are immense. Going to be worth it when I get it on switch as well!
Both challenging and very fun!! Love the game's style too!

Genuinely phenomenal.

Amazing soundtrack, gameplay, art direction, and level design. The difficulty of the main experience felt perfect for me, but there is a lot of additional and more challenging content for those wanting to absolutely master the game.

i already had quite high expectations for antonblast, but it surpassed those expectations and then some.

visually it's oozing with charm and attitude, i absolutely adore how angular and vibrant all of the art across the game is. whether we're seeing the disgusting run-down boiler city or the strangely magnificent [stage 11], it's all done so well. just all these different aesthetics together, unique from one another, but still feeling cohesive. and the expressiveness of all the characters, even the smallest of enemies, is really nice to see; you can gather a lot about their personalities, even if they don't say a word. it's clear that a lot of attention to detail was put in here, and i can tell i'm going to be analyzing and noticing things for a long while.

the music is fantastic as well. the motifs used throughout the game are so exciting to notice, and i love all the callbacks to antonball deluxe. i need a soundtrack release so bad, i want to listen to all of these tracks super closely. for now my favorites are probably cinnamon springs and the final boss theme (trying to be vague here haha).

i've written so much without even touching on gameplay! i grew up with the crash bandicoot games and i could instantly see the inspiration of them in not just the game's interesting clutch boost mechanic, but also the level design itself. 99% of the time when i reached a point where i was struggling with something, it felt very feasible to keep at it and improve until i could beat it, and it was unbelievably satisfying to do so. i could feel myself getting better whenever i made it past a point i was stuck on, and returning to previous levels to clean them up after beating the final boss proved that i had. even though i haven't gotten 100% yet, i'm super excited to get back to it. i can genuinely only count on one hand the amount of times i felt that a segment was a bit too brutal; in general it's challenging, but indescribably fun.

i genuinely cannot recommend this game enough. what a fantastic experience; it was well worth the wait. gotta blast!

If you want to know whether to get Pizza Tower or AntonBlast, It's up to your preference.
Want speed and fast action? Pizza tower!
Want slower but more explorer-style gameplay? AntonBlast!

While many people can compare the two, I like how both stand out. But this is an Anton review, so the rest of this is a review of it.

AntonBlast is simple. Get your spirits back and destroy every level! Along the way, look for treasure, spray cans, and music tapes to spice things up and make you look everywhere. Anton is the perfect game for those who want to find everything a level offers. Combined with gameplay, that's a hybrid or a racing game via the clutch system and a platformer; it's hard to learn but easy to master. But if you can handle it, you'll destroy these levels faster than ranking up a tab at Brulo's.

And don't even mention the awesome bosses. I won't spoil them, but they're a damm blast to beat the snot out of. If you're still on the fence, try the demo. And if you want more, well...THEN BUY THE GAME!

Anton blast is a exploding action pack game bent on putting a big dumb grin on face. All and all this game kicks actual ass and I can't recommend it enough

I love this game and I plan to play it a few more times, but there are many gripes that I have that soured the experience enough for me to try to discuss them online. I just hope that Tony and his team are made aware of some of these issues so Anton Blast and Summit's future projects get the recognition they deserve.

I'll try to be concise:

1. Audio Mixing - I constantly found myself adjusting the sound settings because the sound effects and music really fight for your attention, it's hard to hear both at the same time and the default settings do not sound right (on headphones at least).

2. Visual Clarity - This problem is worse in the earlier levels, the resolution and screen space are limited (I think it matches the GBA), and the levels are detailed so often times the general readability of the level layouts are difficult to process given the speed of the game. In the later levels this is less of an issue because the color palettes are more limited and the platforming challenges have more space between them (tighter jumps).

3. Screen Shake and Camera Lerping - The camera moves VIOLENTLY in this game to really emphasize the power and speed of the player. Even after turning the camera shake down I was still struggling to keep my eyes on Anton in certain levels. This may be the worst in the segments where Anton transforms into a bomb and bounces around so quickly that the camera does not keep up. I've played a lot of high speed action games in my life and was still getting disoriented. I think the camera should try to keep Anton a little closer to the center of screen so players feel like their mistakes are something they have time to avoid.

Despite these issues, I am really impressed with the game overall, the art and music are incredible, the levels are distinct, and I think the passion of the devs flows from the screen like it should. The game MIGHT be a little too difficult but that topic is subjective.

If I had to give any gripes about my experience; The hub to me is a little finicky to maneuver around in, and I do wish the palettes were easier to navigate around, it's a little slow with how it's done and I gotta mash to look thru them (I would suggest maybe being able to hold up/down, or maybe pressing left/right to go to the next available if unlocked!)

Also, I feel like the third boss wasn't very fun at all. It was very slow feeling at the start, then devolved into WAY too much going on that I just struggled and probably won't find myself replaying / dread having to replay in the future.



I've been having nothing but pure fun playing ANTONBLAST, a definitive 8/10 experience. I do hope some of these issues can be resolved, considering I hear work will still be done with the game in the future! Definitely excited for more content being added for it too, cause I know when I truly do EVERYTHING I can, I'm totally gonna be itching for more!!!
!! Just needs more polish all around, but it definitely doesn't detract of the overall experience (Other than the previous stated gripes ofc haha)

A visual blast overselling spiraling levels which don't always explain puzzles, and simple fights due to restrictive player movesets. While a strong start the experience steadily devolves with visual clutter hampering a feel of progression, both for player satisfaction and the 100% incentive as Anton Blast's inspirations lead the end product to feel somewhat aimless but still enjoyable.

(For a similar and somewhat niche alternative I'd recommend Super House of Dead Ninjas)

Waiting for this game since the Kickstater was one of the most worthwhile waits I have experienced. Following the game as closely as I could, any and all expectations I had for this game were completely blown out of the water. Amazing level design, although difficult at no point in my playthrough did any damage I took feel unfair, instead a punishment for going too fast in an unfamiliar place. Funny characters with funny dialogue, and amazing boss fights make this game stand out above other platformers. It doesn't just closely follow it's inspirations, but it appreciates and expands on them to create what feels like an entirely new concept. This game is pumped full of passion and I can't recommend it enough. ANTONBLAST, I love you

This game is a loving send up to the Warioland, Crash Bandicoot, and so much more and it oozes with a style of it's own the entire way through up to a wonderful finish. If you feel that games have been lacking in a specific kind of edge or have a fondness for golden age MTV this will have a place in your library. If you got kids and swear around them they'll probably like this too.

I've only a few minor things I'd change or amend in some way, mainly that visual clarity can be something of an issue during the game's otherwise fantastic (and already very difficult!) ensemble of bosses, what with the intense screen shake and GBA hardware accurate sprite scaling combined with everything mostly sharing the same thick black outlines. Meaning everything from a projectile, rubble kicked up by the player character, and the boss itself can be left fighting for screen estate while you're frantically dodging for your life. Thankfully this seldom is an issue in standard levels but it does happen in at least one stage.

That aside this is a great way to spend 20 bucks and a few days beating, I look forward to more from this team regardless of how that takes shape.

I don't find them very fun, unlike the time trials, and that's because of one small reason. When losing a combo, you lose health. there are also no health crates in the level anymore. By itself, I think these are fun and challenging ways to replay these levels, but together it just gets really annoying. I can totally see someone having fun with this level of challenge, and for an optional challenge I can't really complain too much. I just wish I was able to enjoy this challenge more. I think keeping the damage on losing a combo and just having less health crates than normal would still be a fun challenge, but that's just me lol

This game has been in my periphery for the past howevermany years it was in development. I was anticipating this as the next great wario-like(?) (Its okay, I hate that name too) after Pizza Tower. I think it's not totally unfair to compare the two games on that end, even though that's doing both, but particularly antonblast a diservice. Antonblast has a strong essence all of its own. The gameplay is a lot more hectic than pizza tower, and often invites you to be as reckless as you can wager your hp on. There's no punishments for taking damage or moving slowly. Every timed section doesn't feel so much like a test of level memorization and mastery, and instead feels like a frantic scramble to the door as the world falls apart around you. I would liken this game's timer segments to the musical levels from Rayman Legends, if anything. This game also looks amazing. I loved it, cannot recommend it enough. I'm very proud of the indie scene for producing unique, quality platformers like these.
