I feel really bad for giving this a negative since I backed it, the game is hella crash bandicoot coated, been following the devs for a while, but like, man I am really forcing myself through this and after that last fight I don't think I can for a bit and I feel like I need to express what has been making me not enjoy it to help potentially smooth it out.

Good things though because credit where credit is due, the things the game does right are amazing:
-Fantastic visuals
-Fantastic themeing
-Fantastic music
-Fantastic character design

The whole thing vibes wise is just charming as all hell i dont know what else to say there. You can really feel how much effort and passion went into this game. So much love for the crash bandicoot series too like wow, between the enemy mechanic design and the sound effects there's a lot of stuff I can immediately recognize having played those games. I respect that... which is exactly why it hurts so much to not be having fun with it

The first couple of levels are great, really lets you have fun with the games controls, have good flow to em. Really impressed at the scale of the levels tbh. Then the first miniboss is introduced and immediately a lot of what I feel like the game's persisting problems are crops up:

The game has some strange expectations of the player, and a sense of humor that's kinda funny in hindsight, but not so much to actually play through. A lot of obstacles hit you before you can even register due to the camera, visual effects, sound effects, and overall lack of distinction for some things that would normally help the player register they need to do or avoid something. A lot of the time it feels more like padding than difficulty I should be expected to learn from.

I can't really say most levels are hard as they give you plenty of checkpoints, but they really REALLY like to waste your time by sucker punching you multiple times throughout long or even short segments of gameplay, expecting you to either remember they're all there AFTER you get hit or somehow just know they're coming despite the camera sometimes just holding in a place before lerping back to the player, trying to focus on two things at once, or just not being able to keep up with the speed the player wants to utilize and have. How was I supposed to know there was a nitro just offscreen, why was there a nitro just offscreen in the direction the game knew I'd be holding, why would you do this especially during gimmick sections like the jetpack where you can't snapily change your direction.

I can tell the game has some good feel to it with it's base controls, but it does everything in it's power to make sure I either don't get to use them or get slapped in the face for daring to try. It feels like I have to fight the game for half of each level to just let me play it, in part due to the gimmicks and how unwieldy they are and how lengthy some of their segments can be on top of segments that automate you for a while and then spit you into quick reaction obstacles. I'm not opposed to the crazy gameplay shifts to give a player an experience or some spectacle moments to show something cool, but it gets to the point where I'll be sitting there not understanding what I'm doing, why it's happening, why I'm being punished by taking damage cause i physically cannot see whats on the screen, and how I'm expected to do it better when i end up dying in the middle of it. I get the game's called Anton BLAST but like I'd still like to play the game too. Visual clarity and informing the player on what they're dealing with is important... and I don't think the weird camera has anything to do with the blast part just like, please do SOMETHING with the camera to make it keep up better or show more of the stage.

Some bosses telegraph their attacks pretty well, others telegraph them but there's a dozen things happening on the screen that you need to be aware of at the same time or are just there to distract you, some just kind of hit you with fire or aim lasers in a possition with either no time to react or happen to be possitioned in such a way that if you're in the wrong place you CANT get out of the way in time. You just kinda had to know not to be there. At least if the bosses didn't randomize their attack patterns (BELL), this wouldn't be as much of a problem on repeated attempts, but alas. Sometimes you are just going to take damage. The game does through HP your way to compensate for this, but it feels almost like a compromise rather than something to help you if you're struggling. Like, due to how fancy and flashy the bosses are, it'd be hard to change their attacks once they've been finalized, so instead of making sure the player could reasonably do something hitless, just give them more hp in case they do. There's probably a way to do these fights hitless. I do not want to.

On the note of perfecting and replaying levels, I also don't want to do that, despite the game being built more for exploration than something like pizza tower it feels. The lack of grading puts very little pressure on the player to rush through the stage, especially on their first attempt, which is actually really nice. Definitely more of the crash way to do it. However, this game has a LOT of secrets you can very easily miss on your first go through, because the window to react to getting them is so slim. This, again, would not normally be a problem, encouraging replayability is fine and all, but the game kinda drags you through the stages so much I really REALLY don't want to bother playing them again. Long stages are very impressive! However, long stages have a bit of an issue with replayability in that remembering everything you have to do is very tough, and blink and you'll miss it secrets and blink and you'll miss it obstacles like these mean that if you miss a secret or die, you're gonna have to go through all that again. Even between checkpoints it can be a bit of a drag sometimes.

There's even small nitpicks like switching between Anton and Annie requiring you to go to a specific room in the hub which if you do between levels like I do will take up a lotta time, same with palettes. The diegetic nature of it is cute, but why aren't there more swap points like Brulo's shop? Also god do i wish the game warned you better as to what buying the hat does, cause until I saw a bluesky post about it i thought that giant black mass of pixels covering my hud and various obstacles on the upper portion of the screen was a broken cutscene element that somehow persisted even when i reloaded the game. Funny in hindsight, but not when it comes at the cost of the players experience of the game. It wasn't obvious enough for me to get the joke, i just thought something was wrong with the game and it almost worsened my opinion of it.

I love a difficult game. I can spend 16-20 hours a day playing a game I really enjoy. I could only bare to sit through 2 hours of this one at a time before getting exhausted. I never really get frustrated or angry with games, don't really get why anyone would. I didn't with Anton Blast either, mind you, i just got kinda... sad. Like I felt bad that i wasn't having fun. I figure i was doing something wrong, but it didn't feel fun figuring out what like it normally would, and as i got past stuff, I never even felt like I did figure it out. I will rarely ever give something a negative rating, and usually if i bother to it's because I cared enough about the game and really wanted to enjoy it. I feel like it should be a game I enjoy, and I just don't. I don't really know what can or if anything has to be done to even change the game to fix that, I feel like it'd be a lot. Maybe I'm just an odd outlier, but I hope I can come back to this and really enjoy it someday. I'll try and 100% it at some point if I have the time, but in it's current state I don't know if I will. :(

Yeah okay I'm feeling like Reviewing.

Antonblast is a pretty charming game with a lot of exploration in each level. The music is very high quality for its inspiration and reminiscences of Warioland and Crash Bandicoot. The controls and gameplay are very fluid to use when you aren't forced to do a level gimmicks transportation.

The story is pretty short and sweet. Big devil man sees a guy more red than him and gets furious, sending his moles to trash the place and steal his stuff to motivate Anton to beat the living hell out of him. After that you meet a bar tender who has blacklisted you for stealing spirits, but lucky you! Those spirits are exactly what was stolen from you, so you make a deal to get them back and you get to drink. Simple. The rest is all gameplay until you get to the end which I won't say.

The collectibles are where its at for me. A lot of the items you find are sort of the same thing though, Spraycans for color swaps or Tapes for listening to secrets, etc. But the way you obtain these in certain levels leaves you feeling pretty satisfied and that's what I like about these collectibles, you have no idea where they can be and you have no idea what it could be, a spraycan could turn you into a ghost or a cassette tape plays literal rain drop effects, it's just a bunch of utter nonsense in the good way!

The level designs for the first half of the game are perfection and I have no complaints, though the other half just left me more annoyed than anything, Level 8 has you on a constant timer which you have no choice but to restart the level if you want to get everything, or level 9 with a rocket that has you going all over the place and you will definitely lose points the first time you play this level.

The bosses aren't anything to cry home about, the only necessarily good ones are the "BIG" bads You'd see after the first mole and third mole. The fourth mole boss is cool in concept but it might be my least favorite boss I have fought against in a long time. You essentially run around dodging normal enemies and curse words the entire battle and you have to make sure the dramameter doesn't fall to the tragedy side. If it falls to tragedy, you make no progress and the fight continues on until you eventually get to the actual "Fight" where you play a game of Volleyball with an over sized tomato. Yeah. Sounds all cool on paper but the actual fights the last five seconds.

I also found the first half of the levels to be extremely well done. But the other half were hit or miss for me. My least favorite level has to be the mall level as I mentioned before as level 8. No offense but I don't appreciate a level where the entirety of it is put on a timer and if you are too slow or want to explore it all at your leisure, then chances are you won't be getting the spirit at the end. The enemies in this level were also just made to slow you down and not even hurt you. The cameras, the green blobs, the jumping trash goblins, everything, I had to replay this level four times just because I couldn't find everything in time and that pissed me off.

The last complaint I have is the level transport gimmicks, stuff like the Pinball ball, Bomb body and Jetpack. While I do appreciate some of these, a lot of them are very hard to control and if you have bad timing and handling, you could die very easily and be forced to retry again from the last checkpoint or during "ITS HAPPY HOUR!."

Speaking of, "IT'S HAPPY HOUR" is a lot of fun. I love how so many levels just devolve into utter chaos in the background and foreground as you are racing by in an attempt to escape while slamming enemies out of the way with your giant mallet. It feels like being a pyromaniac and using a NUCLEAR flamethrower BABY! No issue with the timer either, its VERY generous for someone who isn't fond with Wario-Likes, like myself.

Overall that covers basically everything I feel like sharing with my experience on this game. The game is REALLY good, creative, filled to the brim with chaos and insanity, fun visual and audio effects and a plethora of BLASTING gameplay. I honestly just wish there were more levels to play though.

(THIS REVIEW CONTAINS SPOILERS. PLAY THE ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ GAME NOW IF YOU HAVEN'T ALREADY.)

As of writing this review, I have a little over 6 hours in. I already beat the game but did not go for any collectibles. It was a TAD short, but holy mother of ♥♥♥♥ were those 6 hours a BLAST!!!

This is, beyond the SHADOW of a doubt, the BEST game I've ever played. And I've played Spider-Man 2018, Undertale, Omori, Pizza Tower, Wario Land 4, Shovel Knight, Minecraft, Terraria and other titans of gaming. This takes the cake and eats it in front of them all with a smile.

First thing to note is the art style. What could I even say? It is breathtakingly stanky and zesty! It captures 2000's punk graphiti flawlessly and it fits the game's vibes like a glove

The music made me realize our ears each have a g-spot and this game knows how to pound it to dust EVERY time you boot up a new level. It draws obvious inspo from Wario Land (Sometimes with literal instruments and sound samples), Crash Bandicoot, Donkey Kong Country and even a bit of Sonic. EVERY level's theme is grand!

The level design is... Okay, I'll admit, it has a few kinks to work out. Most levels are great, but some are either lacking in visual theme (Some levels just feel like arrays of a color of various shades. Looking at you, factory and Concrete Jungle) or it doesn't properly convey what you need to do or go. Some level's gimmicks are better than others

The characters are ALL lovable and great!! Even the antagonist, Satan, is a lovable ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, dare I say the BEST character

The game's humor had me rolling, and I can watch South Park and Family Guy with a straight face

The transformations are all SO fun to use!! They fit each respective level perfectly and don't feel annoying or out of place, and they last the perfect amount of time

The hub world is a tiny bit easy to get lost but it's really fun, cozy and great to explore! There's probably stuff I missed

The bosses are hit or miss. Mostly with how some don't give you proper info on how to deal with them. Some bosses just need you to keep hitting them, others require you to remember patterns. Does the game ever tell you which are which? Almost never

Now, onto the final boss. Spoilers ahead

I started following this crew right after they released Antonball Deluxe, and was there to see and back the Kickstarter for ANTONBLAST. Two years after the campaign, and with the game out in the wild now... ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.

Granted, there are a few launch day kinks that could use some tending to, especially with a couple of bosses, but other than that, this is an immaculate game and what I believe is the result of Summitsphere being able to just go crazy and do whatever they wanted. The game OOZES charm and creativity and wraps it into the deceptively simple movement of Anton and Annie, which made me end up at the last level of the game in only my first play session. Without spoilers, there are also levels and other various sections of the game that, being at least semi-proficient in GameMaker (the engine this game is made in), made me lose my damn mind and visualize how they were able to pull them off on a technical level.

Summitsphere have a long and prosperous future ahead of them, and you can be certain I'll be first in line for what comes next. Congratulations, guys; you deserve it.

If you like Pizza Tower and the dead whale corpse that is the Wario Land franchise, this game is a must. Anton Blast places an emphasis on destruction and sort of going on a power trip - brilliant stress relief, I must say. The presentation is impeccable: Incredible art style with astonishing attention to detail the whole way through, everything has a very carefully-considered purpose in it. Even the skins have references in them, some of which are super obscure! The sound design is hilarious, especially if you watched Cartoon Network or Looney Tunes as a kid. And oh, lord, the music! The music blows every other game like it out of the water, I cannot sing enough praises about it. Actually getting into a level, the platforming is a good challenge; I'd compare it to Rayman 1. You'll definitely feel tested in many areas, and, true to how the game is designed, there's boundless secrets all over the place. There are plenty of reasons to replay those levels, there's a lot you can get out of them. The developers have oodles of passion and a brilliant sense of humour, and it shows in spades.

But that Rayman 1 comparison is sort of where some issues come from. The controls are a little wonky; the stages are designed with precision in mind, but sometimes you don't fully feel in control. I can't count the number of times - in my 9 hours of gameplay, mind you - where I'd barely miss a jump, succeed after a few tries, and not really know what I did wrong before. There's a little bit of screen crunch (especially in the ball segments) that makes it hard to make precise judgements as well, so you get that Rayman 1 leap of faith thing in it. I also find that the boost mechanic being mapped to the same button as the hammer flip by default is a big mistake when the platforming is so clearly centred around the latter, as you'll have times where you input the hammer flip a bit late but get a boost instead: If you know how different these movement options are, you'll know why that's a big issue! Outside of this, I think some levels (particularly the one with the monkeys) are still a bit undercooked in that they're a bit buggy. I had severe issues with the wall clinging stages in particular, where I'd sometimes start crawling the wrong way, and sometimes I would get stuck in level geometry; I believe these are both due to going too fast.

Finally, I think the transformations are a very, very mixed bag. They seem to have taken a backseat compared to the other games, and I think that is for the best with how many are designed. The sole transformation I think I fully enjoyed was the robot one, and that was because it was finally something easy to control. It got to the point that I was sort of dreading these by the end of it, because I vastly preferred the hammer-flipping and boosting gameplay otherwise offered. The pinball transformation was a little too much like Sonic Spinball in the worst ways; the torpedo and jetpack are extremely unforgiving for their jerky controls; so on, so forth. Besides that, I think too many of them were "you are now forced to go in this direction" for the amount of stages, I would have liked more inspiration from the other "Wario-likes" on this account.

Overall, a very fine addition to the recent "platformer where you're just a really intense Mario who swears like a sailor" shindig, but I want to see more...from the game, and the shindig. Further proof that the platformer genre has a lot of growing to do.

For disclosure, I did volunteer playtest this game before its release.

This game has come a long way since the Kickstarter demos. The spectacle, the music, the variety in stages, and, most of all, the detail in the animations is all an unstoppable force. The game definitely gets stronger as it goes on, too, so if you think it's "pretty good" at the beginning, you're in for a treat as it ramps up. The bosses, particularly the full-size bosses, are a ton of fun and satisfying to beat. It also made me laugh out loud more than a few times.
This game is definitely hard. However, it very rarely feels hard due to slippery controls or intentional obfuscation of information. Once you figure out what it wants from you, it's very fun to master. The last main level is a gauntlet that may take many tries, which I honestly think is a good thing.
I think it will truly flourish as more patches roll in to smooth out the last of the bugs and add in the extra content, which they have already been pretty responsive about. I think the one warning I would make is that Photosensitivity Mode is not yet fully implemented, and some bosses, particularly later ones, can contain a good amount of flashing. I am not usually a 2D platformer person, but I'm going to be thinking about this one for years.

ANTONBLAST is a perfect game. It has 12 levels and eight bosses, all providing around 3-5 hours of content. The game also has plenty of collectibles to get, providing an extra optional challenge for anyone with nothing to do after beating the game. The game also has 2 playable characters, Anton and Annie, each with their own small storyline. Each level is full of things to do, and it all flows well. If you have the money, I'd advise picking it up.

I've been following the games development for about 2 years now and seeing it slowly grow to what it became is nothing but crazy. i new it was going to be good but THIS GOOD? yeah no this game is definitely game of the year material.

Antonblast is HARD, do not go into it thinking it'll be a walk in the park. Don't buy cosmetics, instead save up for when the permanent health upgrades show up in the shop, trust me you'll need them. I'd compare Antonblast to Pizza Tower moreso than Warioland 4, despite it being inspired by the latter it shares a lot more with the former, being focused on speed and reaching the end as fast as possible rather than the puzzle focused gameplay of WL4.

The art is amazing and I really like the voice acting, there is genuine love put into this game, but I have to reiterate how brutal this game is, be prepared for frustration unless you're a platforming god. I was stuck on the final level for longer than I'd care to admit. If difficulty isn't a dealbreaker, then you'll definitely enjoy the game.

This is the closest thing to Warioland 4 that you can find easily available today. I haven't played Antonblast a lot yet but I've been running the demo on Switch multiple times. I can say, I really do enjoy this game.
It is more difficult than Warioland 4 or at least the stages are. I could say that the bosses might be a bit easier despite having pretty similar healthbars. In the first boss at least at the second phase, you get a checkpoint when in Warioland 4, if you screw up then you gotta start all over. Again however, in this game you have only three hearts. In Warioland 4 you have 8.

Backer #102 here - my review doesn't impact the game's ratings as indicated by the greyed out star.

Antonblast has a lot of potential with its amazing soundtrack, fun voice acting, and impressive art direction—you can really feel the love poured into this game.

The animations, while well-crafted, don’t always suit the game’s small resolution during gameplay, making it hard to follow the action (though the cutscenes look stellar). Even with accessibility options, the visual clutter can be overwhelming at times, with excessive shaking and flashing effects - an option to lower the brightness of the background to make the player and enemies stand out would be appreciated, in my opinion.

Some tiny bugs here and there can occur, I've experienced mild stuttering to broken full-screen with the game only taking a quarter of my screen, fixed by a reboot, alongside some weird game interactions with gimmicks, but nothing game-breaking.

What could be a fun and dynamic platformer can occasionally feel headache-inducing.
The transition from fast-paced gameplay to precise platforming can be a bit off-putting at times. With the clear Crash Bandicoot inspiration, an all-around "easy" mode would be a welcome addition, avoiding the need to buy items to make certain levels easier.

Don't underestimate the difficulty of the game. I came out of most levels feeling frustrated by the difficulty of certain parts, rather than being in awe of the great cinematics and events.

That said, the game shines with its varied levels, rich themes, and a colorful cast of characters.
If you're up for a challenge and can push past the chaos, there’s a lot to enjoy here.

AntonBlast is one of the best games I've ever played.
The game has a constant chaotic nature to it that just makes you want to destroy everything on your path, but also rewards you for taking your time and exploring the levels for collectables. It's pretty challenging and has a lot of Trial and Error moments SPECIALLY if you've never played the demos, but once you pull it off it's incredibly satisfying.
This game is also surprisingly beefy. Don't get me wrong it's not like some 20+ hours game that'll keep you entertained for the rest of your life, but, for 20 bucks, the game has more than enough to keep you coming back every now and then.
The graphics are beautifully animated and give off strong vibes of early 2000's cartoons that would constantly make you ask yourself "How did they get away with this ?", all topped off with an incredibly funky soundtrack that made me stop playing multiple times just so I could listen to it.
The story is very silly in my opinion, but it really just completes my previous point. The character designs, personalities and their interactions all come along to really make it feel like you're just watching an episode.
I wholeheartedly recommend this game for anyone who's interested in chaotic experiences, weird cartoons or just platformers in general. It really is a once in a lifetime experience that I wish I could play for the first time again.

Game Of The ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Year. Backed this one over 2 years ago knowing fully well Summitsphere was capable of pulling it off after Antonball Deluxe and they still blew any expectations I had out of the stratosphere. This is gonna be a Platinum standard for the 2D platformer genre now.

Like Pizza Tower before it, Antonblast is an extremely laborious project of burning passion for gaming and animation, so thoroughly synthesizing aspects of the inspirations it has while adding Summitsphere's special flavor to stand firmly on its own 2 feet, both mechanically and aesthetically. It's unique take on the Wario Land 4 level format is propped up by extremely buttery smooth controls and incredibly responsive animation, along with the level design feeding you through such an adrenaline pumping rampage in deeply cathartic and SUPER explosive destruction. And on that note, the art and sound direction mesh together to form such a rock solid and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ KICKASS identity. This is easily some of the greatest sprite vfx work ive ever seen in a game. I've had ideas about some of the stuff they pulled off visually here and it's ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ GLORIOUS!!!!!!And the soundtrack. Tony Grayson is on the upper echelon of VGM composers for me now, holy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ ♥♥♥♥ dude. Such an incredible use of digital fusion music that just gets you PUMPED. THATS THE KINDA ♥♥♥♥ I LIKE TO SEE!!!!!!!!!!!!!! (level 4's and 12's music especially bring me to joyful tears)

All and all, Antonblast sits right next to Pizza Tower not only as part of a new guard of the spirit of the Wario Land games that inspired them, but as an outstanding pioneer showing where indie games and the 2D platformer genre are capable of going in the modern age of digital art and game dev technology. I still have a LOT to do for 100% cleanup, and I haven't been able to do deep dives in the new modes yet, but I can abso♥♥♥♥inglutely say that this game is worth your time and money. So damn excited to see whatever Summitsphere does next. BUY ANTONBLAST WITH MONEY™️!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!1!!!!

Peak in every conceivable way.

As many others, I was introduced to Anton through the ever-popular Pizza Tower game (Don't worry, I'm not here to compare the two like a loser!). I enthusiastically followed development and bought it the exact minute it released.

It throws you into the game and immediately you can tell this game has a sweet style. There's so much charm in the intro and stage beginning, it really hooks you in. The mechanics are easy to learn but hard to master, which I feel is fantastic for keeping the game beginner-friendly.
Game simple: Break stuff, watch number go up, jump platforms, kill people with hammers and whatnot, mad dash for exit under a timer. As the game progresses so many new mechanics, styles, enemies, gimmicks, and more just burst from the seams and it constantly keeps you invested!
There's such an unruly amount of satisfaction that comes from destroying everything and plowing your way through the level, clutch by clutch. That satisfaction you feel when you overcome an obstacle that was previously holding you down is something to behold!

The bosses, similarly, are fantastic. They all have fantastic movesets that balance difficulty and patterns. Admittedly, they can get a bit tight at times and it can get overwhelming to understand what's happening, but you get used to it as the game goes by. Trial and error, my friend!
Each boss has outstanding movesets and sweet cutscenes, sometimes separate phases can completely change the way you play! They're so dang engaging.

Now this game... gets difficult. Nothing too insane, but do keep in mind there will undoubtedly be multiple attempts in the later levels/bosses. That final boss especially, whew, they're a tricky one.
But what I love is how well this game seamlessly dips you farther and farther into the pool until you have to swim on your own. You're unconsciously learning to master your movement as it goes on, until it puts you to the test in the finale.

Not even mentioning the different gamemodes to try, collectibles to find, costumes, witty and not-so-witty-yet-embarrassingly-funny humor, this is for sure one of my favorite games of the year 2024.

If you love yourself some chaos, explosions, platforms, and cartoons, this game should be right down your alley!

For a game that was backed in 72 hours, Antonblast truly delivered something special.
Its an incredible title that is an absolute must-play treat for anyone into platformers, especially Crash Bandicoot and Wario with how massive of a love-letter it is to the two franchises. Coupled with some of the best game music I've heard in the last several years of game releases, its no wonder this game took longer than expected to release; the team's passion is really evident.
The gameplay is paced quite well, though, everyone giving it a try should realize its explicitly not always a speed game. Nearly each level has a unique gimmick to it that helps really break up how you can explore, and the amount of secrets really add to the replayability of each stage.
The game's animation style really shines thanks to its humor being a solid mix of both hilarious old inside jokes and late-night cartoon gags. Voicework and dialogue really add to this a ton, especially with Satan's absolutely delightful performance by Gianni.
The music in particular is what helps make this game even more insanely special; Not only is each track incredibly unique, but the team's smart use of a dynamic soundtrack that changes thru the levels just adds so much pizzazz to it. The musical references are over-the-top radical too, with so many nostalgic samples from its inspired games to new takes on musical styles (one part of a level even has a chunk of acapella to reference Crash Twinsanity). Tony really pulled it off with flying colors.

The only nitpicks (that will without a doubt be ironed out) is the balancing in the later parts of the game is a bit difficult but not impossible. A teeny tiny handful of bosses need better tells on attacks and I-frames, namely the final boss. There's a small handful of parts that lack SFX that would definitely assist the player a bit and up the experience. Only noticed a tiny number of bugs that have already been brought up and will obviously be gone within a few months time.

All in all, seeing this project grow up in the time that it took has been really invigorating as a still-learning game dev and a real paragon of how indie dev with a close knit group of buddies can truly pay off. Hats off to the team for really nailing it!

If you want a BLASTIN' good time and are a glutton for punishment, then Antonblast is for you. Gluttony may be a sin, but this game sure as hell isn't! With a ridiculously 90's cartoon aesthetic, high-speed action-packed gameplay, ball-busting difficulty, and soundtrack that'll blow your mind to smithereens, Antonblast is simply a must-play.

I was one of AntonBlast's many Kickstarter backers, and seeing it evolve in the years since that campaign has been incredibly exciting. And now that I've played through the game, I can easily say that I'm very glad I chose to back this.
Pun entirely intended, this game is an absolute blast.

It's filled to the brim with both charm and surreal-ness in its visuals and set pieces, it's got incredibly fun and challenging gameplay that continuously finds ways to keep each level and boss fight feeling fresh from the last, and it's got a superb soundtrack all throughout, just to name a handful of its strengths. And as a longtime Crash Bandicoot fan, the many ways this game homages the series (without ever feeling like it's reliant on Crash's legacy to carry it) continuously put a smile on my face.

Even with a couple shortcomings here and there, this is 100% a must-play for any platformer fan, and it's easily my personal game of the year.

As someone who backed the Kickstarter and has played every public demo to this game, I can say that I am extremely satisfied with the final result of this game; It's colorful, flashy, and has a lot going for it. Despite the game's difficulty, I had a big stupid grin on my face most of the way through.

After 4 years of development, a hurracaine and a thriving community later, Anton finally painted the town, the city and other countries red, I cannot express how much fun is to destroy, splat and scream every level with added goodies! You NEED to support summitsphere, I sure did, why wouldn't you?

Truly a modern classic! It really does sell how it feels to be a destructive, rampaging unstoppable force like Anton.

It's loud, exaggerated but edgy cartoon aesthetic would feel right at home with animated shows that aired on MTV in the '90s, like Beavis and Butt-Head or The Maxx. This game has a ton of really cool and unique settings for a platformer that you really just need to see for yourself to get the most out of them. I also LOVED how dynamic and cinematic all the bosses were.

Despite the fast pace the game also doesn't sacrifice exploration at all, with levels tending to be very expansive with plenty of hidden away optional areas, usually having interesting side content within them.

Overall, if you're a fan of stylized, fast-paced action games this is such an easy recommend.

The developers really nailed making you feel like a wrecking ball. It's incredibly fun to destroy everything in your path as your point total goes up. There's even a bit a more precise platforming for secrets, which is often rewarding. I would say some parts are a bit hard to understand on the first go around, such as what each button does during a transformation or how a boss is supposed to be defeated. Once everything clicks, though, it's a ton of fun.

ANTONBLAST is awesome. It was fun pretty much all of the way through, and it'll be fun to go through the levels to get everything hidden throughout and maybe even go through the time trials! Maaaybe. I don't know if I'm ready to speedrun some of these levels yet.

I played the demo before I got the game, and let me say this game makes pizza tower look tame! I can see tons of crash bandicoot references or nods, and as a huge platformer fan and love of Crash Bandicoot games in general, it scratches that itch while you're going 200 miles per hour! Honestly there's so much in this game, each level is chaos. The characters are fun, the reference to the devil from cow and chicken is a fun touch.

Also, the biggest thing I want to point out is I love the sound effects! It sounds SUPER arcadey and it's done so well; the first time I jumped and my hammer hit the ground and I started spinning in the air hearing it spin around blazing through the level sounded SO COOL! I felt like I could walk through an arcade and it's sound effects would fit right in next to the other games there. Also it's got a yell button, great feature.

The precision platforming isn't always necessary from what I've seen, only if you want to get all those hidden goodies. Usually you don't have to do super precise jumps going stupid fast which I appreciate.

So if you liked pizza tower and wanted something even crazier, this definitely fits the bill. Long story short, I'm having a BLAST!

- EDIT: Revising my review -

I really liked Pizza Tower, it became my sole focus for maybe a year, I'm still modding it occasionally.

Anton Blast though, it tickled something lost to me for years. Something Pizza Tower didn't, it tickled the part of my brain that Wario Land 4 did when I played it on the GBA, and arguably went beyond.

First, the visuals. They scream 2000s in so many ways and emulate the best parts of art that I would say the GBA featured. 3D, claymation, all kinds of fantastical visuals that capture your eyes. They game can sometimes be such a visual spectacle that I get ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ overloaded, thankfully not to the point that it hindered gameplay. It looks so good, I cannot explain it.

The movement is in my opinion, a tough shell to crack, but very much in the sonic sense, where it really takes time and practice. Thankfully, the game is built so that even if you can't play like a pro, you can still beat it.

DIFFICULTY, damn ♥♥♥♥♥!!! It's not cuphead but its getting close, it kicked my ass at the end, but not in a way where I got too frustrated or tired of playing. I'm personally ♥♥♥♥ at games, I can't beat DS3, but I managed to beat this game in about 6 hours while I was going nonstop (and ignoring the ridiculous amount of collectibles)
That being said, it was a welcome difficulty, one that I gotta be real, Pizza Tower doesn't have. It's challenge comes from P ranks, which is fantastic, but I never felt opposed on my first playthrough. Hell Manor felt like a real fight, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.

MUSIC, its a bop, simple as, the only crime is it's not on youtube yet and I'm not sure it all the songs have been posted anywhere.

My only gripe is it can't be modded. If the devs are reading reviews, please allow modding through UTMT, I'm desperate to mod this game like I did with PT. I wanna make levels and character skins PLEASE
I give it a BLAST out of 10.

This game is a wonderful compiled collection of levels that add CRAZY gimmicks! Anton and Annie control fantastically and have been done justice in the way they play and feel. The first half of the game was OH-SO FABULOUS!!!!!

I do have some major complaints though.

1. The latter half of the game has some stages in them that become infuriating to the point where things start to make less sense. I'm looking at you, Pinball stage and Level 12.
2. The overall difficulty curve was unwarranted. Seriously. And I get that Crash was its main inspiration, but the two mentioned stages were genuinely just bad in my opinion.
3. The first phase of Satan's fight is sooo baffingly jarring. It's SO frustrating to where all I could think of were how badly I wanted this character dead. SPOILER TERRITORY: but that first phase needs fixes, BADLY. It reeeaally hurt to see the



And finally, the general feeling I have for this game is...
It's complicated. The first half of the game was groundbreaking, a juggernaut, while a fat majority of the latter half just either genuinely blew to go through or just felt... less fun. I can't say I don't love this game, though.

What is there to really say that hasn't already been said years before? The game is a masterpiece!
The controls at first do seem a little demanding, and at times might feel weird, but once you get used to it after the first few levels, you become a real pro! The visuals are amazing, and there was no point in the game where the art was bad.
Level Design wise, was also amazing. Sometimes continuity felt strange, but it never hurt the game-play experience, sometimes actually helping it. For those who are interested in the game, just know that this game DOES get demanding in the latter half. Especially near the end, this game is not for the weak. Other specific things to note is that the game is very replay-able, and encourages it with collectibles, cosmetics to unlock, and more!

Overall: This game is an amazing 6-hour experience, but it's definitely worth every penny, pound, and euro of your purchase! The game's humor is also well done. I am satisfied with the final product.

For one final thing, I did encounter a few bugs, but I'm sure those will get patched out, if not already.

If you've got 20 buckaroonies to spare, BUY THE GAME! PLEASE!

Only halfway through the game's story at the time of writing this but this game might genuinely be my favourite game I played this year. The levels are all unique with different vibes and phenomenal music accompanying them. The bosses so far are also really well designed, they're difficult if you don't know what you're doing, but also challenging should it finally click what you gotta do. I backed the game in mid 2022 and I've been watching how the game evolved throughout the two and a half years and even with what's been revealed and shown by the devs and PR team already, I still find new things to cherish, appreciate, have a little giggle or even laugh uncontrollably about. ANTONBLAST is genuinely a work of love and passion. I'm happy to have supported the game's development financially back then and I'm happy to support the game even further by purchasing the soundtrack when it ever becomes available.

If you haven't checked the game out and are looking for a snappy, action-packed platformer with Wario Land 4 and Crash Bandicoot influences, do not miss out on this game. If not on sale, this game is easily the worth the 20 US dollars and it's guaranteed you'll have a ton of fun, if not a BLAST. Just make sure to not go fast immediately. Instead take it slow and learn the stages until you're comfortable rushing through them.

ANTONBLAST is one of the best games I have ever played. Am I biased? Probably, I was a community playtester for it. But no matter what, this game is genuinely fantastic. It is filled with so much charm, style and attitude that you can't help but be drawn in by all the chaos. The story is simple because it doesn't need to be anything else, and it's damn funny too. The gameplay is easily the best part, every move flows into each other beautifully and makes traversing the 12 sprawling levels a joy. The music is absolutely stellar. The game's director and composer, Tony Grayson, knocked it out of the park. Everyone at Summitsphere knocked it out of the park, you can feel everyone's influence on the game's direction throughout the game.

Hats off to you, Summitsphere. You've made a stellar game. Now drink up, my friends! It's happy hour!

what i don't like:

a lot of levels look the same

seemingly debug features left on in cut scenes
confusing mechanics with no tutorialising
air movement isn't very fun to control as it is too floaty moving left and right
many invisible destructables in levels

what i do like;

the bosses were pretty good

Really excellent platformer. It's hard to express exactly why it is so good because every single aspect of it is some of the most impressive the genre has ever seen.
Its strongest characteristic is the fact that it is very willing to completely throw away gimmicks and ideas level to level and introduce new mechanics in a way that is very confident in itself. That confidence is earned, as every level here on display is impressive beyond belief and is never left feeling under-explored mechanically. It has no levels that are of lesser quality than each other, which is a miracle, considering how easy it is to have just a single level that's just slightly worse than the rest. But it never happens.
It's clear to me this is a game made by people who love video games and I cannot recommend it enough if you love video games too.

I knew Anton in highschool and he would literally pay boys to let him blast all over them. One of my friends had drug addicted parents that didn't give him any lunch money and he would see Anton in Brulo's Casino multiple times a week just because his stomach would hurt so much during 1st period from blasting. I didn't know at the time, it was only after we met up in our 2nd year of college and had some drinks that he opened up about it. I assumed he was only doing so because he was tipsy but apparently he had lots of sessions with Satan to try and deal with it. The most disturbing thing about his story was that Anton was obsessed with balls, his fantasy was to blast balls all over the screen. My friend of course didn't own Antonball Deluxe so he had trouble keeping the balls on the screen for awhile, and often times Anton got so frustrated with the lack of blasting that he would deny my friend any payment and storm off, leaving him in tears. But slowly Anton got better with practice and was soon forcibly making the poor guy blast with his technique. As I'm hearing all this ♥♥♥♥ I would have been in complete disbelief, had I not witnessed how my friend acted during and after lunch break. I always assumed he was crying because of his family problems, I always thought he was distant because Brulo always belittled him. But now I know, and I feel truly wish that were me in that scenario, and I don't feel sorry for him.

ANTONBLAST is an epic, blood-pumping 2D experience featuring our one and only dynamite man Anton (and his substance-abusing co-star Annie) as he descends down to hell to kick Satan himself's arse for stealing all his booze. Of course, it's not without recently divorced Brulo's help.

I first and foremost recommend this blast of a game the most to disgruntled Nintendo fans starving for any Wario content that isn't Ware since 2008, 'cause boy, if Pizza Tower wasn't enough dinner on the table, THIS is the dessert everybody's looking for. It's got just right amount of fluid gameplay, crazy (and) good artstyle, bangin' soundtrack (props to Tony Grayson!), and everything else. You'll find yourself replaying this game more than once, with how addictive it was designed to be, thanks to the two additional game modes, and way more. In this game, rushing through the stages like a wrecking ball just HITS that spot in the brain. There aren't enough words for me to shill this game, so please, your wallet is yearning for you to press that purchase button!

For transparency, I playtested the game extensively. 43 hours doesn't come from nowhere.

But more than that, I saw this game from the very earliest prototypes. Pre-kickstarter. I've been friends with the developers since the release of Antonball Deluxe. This game has shaped up and stepped up in quality constantly over it's storied development. The game's been delayed a few times. But believe me, Miyamoto's quote is right on the money. "Antonblast is really good!" he says. Damn right, Shiggy. Damn right.

From the bottom of my heart, I'm proud of Summitsphere. This game kicks so much ass. It is an expression of the team's tastes that sizzles on the tongue and falls down the throat as spicily as one of Anton's spirits. I love this game. I loved testing it. I loved helping on marketing materials. I loved backing it! I love Anton! I wish Satan was my husband!

But seriously, this game will kick your ass. Get ready for that. It ain't for the faint of heart. Do you like secret hunting? There are SO many secrets in this game. SO MANY. Check the hub, check all the levels. So much to find for the curious. Do you like speedrunning? You'll find there's a LOT to do on that front. Hop back into any level for new challenges. Do you like increasingly obscure references to things the development team like? Check Brulo's shop after every level. Do you like Blake? The red "Welcome To Server" dog from the Summitsphere discord? He's in the game. Go look.

Antonblast has so much to give, and it's gonna be giving for a WHILE. What a game, what a game. Incredible.

After playing this game thoroughly and experiencing it as a whole, my experience was... surprisingly negative. Many of this game's strong points (of which there are a good amount) are bogged down heavily by confusing design decisions that make moment-to-moment gameplay feel awkward and infuriating. I'll try to compile my honest thoughts and critical feedback at a later date, but in a nutshell, it feels like the experience of the player is treated as an afterthought, and it results in the game as a whole kicking significantly less ass during gameplay than you would expect it too.
